title: Fix the releases URL
body: Currently it points to an older release. This new link ensures it will always point to the latest release.
author: navjotjsingh

title: Laptop doesn't boot anymore
body:
I mistakenly "patched" my installed SSD harddrive with the USB Patch instead of the Installation Drive while creating the Boot Drive. After this my laptop stucks on boot, showing f2, f9 or F12 menu, but doesn't react on hitting one of these keys. After removal of my SSD i can start my uefi BIOS. 
So the Patch seems to have "killed" my SSD.
How can i "repair" the SSD, so that it reacts anymore or that i can reinstall Windows on it?
author: chrisch4n

comments.body: this is more than strange and technically NOT impossible. To roll back the patch, just delete the entire $OEM$ folder in the sources directory ..if its even created?

It's alive again.
I repaired my system Partition and uefi boot (had to install the SSD into a USB case) and it works again.

title: Issue with Method 1: Restart to normal (Windows10) login screen
body:
Hello!

I tried Method 1, download and mounted the Iso, Initiate update, then in the Blue "Installing Windows Server - Your PC will restart several times (...)" Goes until 60 something percent complete, then restarts but to the it's the usual login screen. I login to my usual Windows10, no further messages.

Has anyone encountered a similar behaviour? How can I know what's causing the update to fail?

Thanks!
author: Bakadori

comments.body: hi, so this means that the installation starts, runs up to about 60%, and then essentially stops, so the system continues to boot into your Windows 10 without rolling back or making any other changes?

Exactly that, no changes that I'm aware of. 

When I used the ISO downloader I selected Windows 11 and English International, Release, Edition and architecture had no options to choose from (24H2, W11 Home/Pro/Edu, x64). ISO gets mounted to D: . During Windows Server Setup in the Get updates, drivers and optional features, I've tried both Download updates (recommended) and Not right now options. After that, Keep files, settings and apps.

 I don't know if there are any logs I can look at or share with you.

Well well well, I tried it once more with the ISO I had already downloaded and when I came back to it bang! Windows 11 baby. I don't think I did anything different, besides maybe leaving it alone for longer.
